question: What's the money for?
answer: A new pair of panty hose. Is it enough?

question: I don't want your money. You're a booger.
answer: It was Brady's idea, Jane. Honest to God. Please take the money. I want to make up.

question: I can get a pair of L'Eggs down at the pharmacy for a dollar forty-nine. Here.
answer: That's for you, too. Uncle Al gave it to me- -but I want you to have it. Yeah, go ahead.

question: Not bad, huh? My Uncle Al took off the regular muffler and put on a Cherry Bomb.
answer: What's that?

question: Glasspack. He said he'd come over sometime this summer and we'd soup up the engine... but now I dunno. He's getting a divorce and he's in the doghouse with my mother.
answer: For getting a divorce?

question: Well... it is his third.
answer: The other kids are gone; they are alone. The sidewalk has ended and they roll slowly along the dirt verge of the road. They look toward: Thanks for coming with me, Marty- I was scared to go past her house by myself. I mean, I saw her. All the time. I used to see her every day, and she never knew what was going to happen to her, and neither did I! I mean I know how stupid that sounds, but...

question: Hey, take it easy. I know how you feel.
answer: There's something else scary.

question: What?
answer: I've been hearing noises in there.

question: What kind of noises?
answer: Rattling. Rustling.

question: Rats...
answer: And my dad says it's kids. But it's not rats and it's not kids. It's-

question: I'd go out and take a look myself, but I think the Bullet'd get stuck in the garden. It looks sorta greasy.
answer: You would, wouldn't you? Well, it's probably nothing. I'm just spooked since... you know.

question: Yeah... but if you hear any more noises, tell your father. Okay?
answer: Okay. Have you got enough gas to get home, Marty?

question: I'm always doing this! I gotta go, Tammy.
answer: I like him.

question: Well, Marty! I see you lucked out again!
answer: Yep. Would you fill it up, please, Mr. Cutts?

question: Want me to check the oil?
answer: Sure!

question: Wipe the windshield an check the driver's bullshit level?
answer: Okay, okay. I call.

question: Let the boy finish the game, Nan.
answer: Make it quick.

question: Three kings. Bullshit luck!
answer: I don't want you drinking around Marty. That's too much. If you can't stop it, you better stay away.

question: I come here because Marty needs a friend.
answer: Yes... you've always been that to him. But if you can't leave your booze in whatever dump you call home, you better just stay away.

question: Mom was really mad at him this time, wasn't she?
answer: What do you expect, when he comes in smelling like a brewery and looking like an unmade bed?

question: Stop it!
answer: He's okay, Dad!

question: Yes. Go away.
answer: Let me help you up.

question: Brady! Get out of my way!
answer: Stay off the bandstand, Herb.

question: Is it my boy? Is it Brady?
answer: Don't go up-

question: You all right, Marty?
answer: Yeah.

question: There's a saying- so-and-so was better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick. You ever hear that one?
answer: No.

question: Well, I'm not sure that was. Christ! They better get the guy.
answer: Uncle Al, what if it's not a guy?

question: Huh?
answer: What if it's some kind of monster? What's going on at Owen's, Uncle Al?

question: A bunch of men getting ready to pretend they're Clint Eastwood... Marty, didn't anybody ever tell you that the only monsters are in comic books and drive-in movies?
answer: Tammy said she'd been hearing noises in that greenhouse. Growling noises, like a big animal. Her father was killed that night.

question: Just remember, it's the psycho we want, not each other. So look before you-
answer: I want all of you folks to go home! I can't remember deputizing a single one of you!

question: That's right, Joe- the only deputy you got is that fat shitbag beside you, and neither one of you has done a damn thing about solving this case. You couldn't catch a cold.
answer: The law has a name for what you men are planning. It's private justice, and private justice is about a step and a half away from lynch mobs and hang ropes. I'm no J. Edgar Hoover, but I am the law in Tarker's Mills, and I want you men to go home.

question: Billy... Billy, this is a bad idea. Joe can...
answer: Let them go.

question: But-
answer: This is that spirit of community you were talking about. Grand, ain't it? Maybe they'll shoot a hitchhiker or something and Andy can mount the head and raffle it off. To benefit the Medcu van, of course.

question: But can't we do anything?
answer: Sure. We can pray to Christ that none of them get killed.

question: Yeah... but what are they doing?
answer: Putting on my Sherlock Holmes deerstalker cap, I deduce that they are leaving. She's not the only one. Lot of people leaving town. And I guess if we want a beer, we'll have to drink it at home.

question: Joe, what's wrong with you? I ain't never seen you like this.
answer: It was the Kincaid boy. I looked at him... and I felt it happen. It was no big deal. No worse than pissing down your own leg. You ever do that? Maybe when you were real scared? One minute I had me some guts- as much as the next man, anyhow- and then, poof. Gone.

question: It isn't enough that the monster killed all those people- that he killed Brady. Now he's got them to cancel the fair.
answer: And the fireworks. Hand me that box, Marty.

question: Yeah, okay, the fireworks. Jane thinks that's all I'm mad about, but it's not. Them doing that is just a... a...
answer: It's just an outward symbol of everything that's inwardly wrong in this town. Not bad, huh? I read Sherwood Anderson in college. I can jive that shit all day.

question: Well... I like it that you always know how to say things, Uncle Al.
answer: I'll give you the telephone numbers of my ex-wives, dear boy- they'll be interested to hear that.

question: Don't call me dear boy.
answer: But you are, you know- you are my dear boy. Look at this. Your mom's not around, is she?

question: She and dad are out back lighting the barbecue. Jane's walking around like she's King Shit of Turd Mountain. Like always.
answer: Uh-huh. Only in her case I guess it would be Queen Shit of Turd Mountain. Hand me that adjustable. The guy killed your best friend, drove your girl out of town, and stole the second-best holiday in the year. Have I got it right? Yeah, Winesburg, Ohio, was never like that... but I got something that just might cheer you up.

question: What?
answer: Wait, dear boy. Just wait. Hand me those pliars. All is cool, Marty-boy. Go for it. Jesus! Not too much! You got a pilot's license, Marty?

question: Do I need one?
answer: We're gonna find out. Take it down the road a ways and back. Be careful. You gave me a heart attack, Marty. I'm dying. I hope you're happy, because you are looking at a dying man.

question: It really goes fast. Thanks, Uncle Al.
answer: It goes fast, all right- and if your mother finds out just how fast, Marty, I will have a new job. Singing soprano with the Vienna Boys' Choir.

question: I don't get you.
answer: I know you don't. But I want this to be our secret. You get that, don't you?

question: Sure.
answer: Good. I've got to go, Nan- I had a wonderful time.

question: See me around to my car, Marty, and make sure I stay out of trouble at least that long.
answer: Okay.

question: Now I said I had something for you, as I believe you will recall.
answer: Yeah! What is it?

question: You're gonna have the Fourth of July in October, Marty. Just don't blow your head off. And remember that it isn't just the fireworks. It's because no crazy shithead should be able to stop the good guys, if you can dig that. Stay near the house, for Christ's sake- someone's killing people. I have to be out of my mind to be doing this, you know.
answer: Yeah, I know. It's great!

question: One of the reasons I love you, Marty, is that you're almost as crazy as I am. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay? Just bright colors. Can you tell the difference?
answer: Yeah... sure.

question: Save this one for last.
answer: What is it?

question: A tracer. You'll like it.
answer: Thanks a million, Uncle Al!

question: Father Lowe? Father Lowe?... I've got my tally sheet... I... I don't feel so well, I guess maybe I got too much sun.
answer: Would you like to come in the parlor and lie down for a bit? Or have a cold drink? I have some soda-

question: No! That is, I have to get home and help my mom with lunch.
answer: I'll give you a ride!

question: No- she... she was going to meet me at the market. I'll be fine.
answer: Give my best to your brother, Jane.

question: It came for me! I shot it in the eye! Now he's wearing an eye-patch!
answer: I called Peltzer on my way over here, Marty! Father Lowe came into the drugstore two days ago for a bottle of otic solution. That's a fancy way of saying eyewash. He's got a corneal inflammation.

question: Was it a prescription?
answer: What the hell does that matter?

question: It wasn't- I'll bet you it wasn't. Because to get a prescription he'd have to see a doctor.
answer: Marty, Marty, you should hear yourself!

question: Well... was it a prescription?
answer: I don't know. But I know you didn't see any werewolf the other night, Marty. You had a dream, that's all. An extremely realistic nightmare brought on by what's been happening in this town.

question: What about the baseball bat Jane saw in his shed? You know who used to have a baseball bat like that? Mr. Knopfler! He was so proud of it he used to carry it in the Fourth of July parade! Jane said it looked like the Green Giant used it for a toothpick!
answer: You want to know what I think?

question: No- we just got you out here so we could admire your pretty face.
answer: Watch it, dear boy. I think it was a hallucination. Probably a broomstick, or something. No thank you, Jane. I'm a little old for palying the Hardy Boys Meet the Catholic Werewolf.

question: I probably shouldn't tell you- you're both hysterical on the subject. I'm starting to feel like a guy handing out free Arthur Murray coupons to victims of the dancing sickness.
answer: Uncle Al, if you don't tell me-

question: No... but I found some blood, smeared on a tree trunk in that grove.
answer: There! You see!

question: It could have been anything, Marty.
answer: What about Father Lowe chasing me in his car and trying to run me down? You don't think that was a dream, do you?

question: Jesus.
answer: That's just about the craziest damn story I've ever heard, Al.

question: I know. I could have edited out all of the completely crazy stuff, but I thought you deserved to hear it with the bark on.
answer: I appreciate that. Now, the next question

question: Let's just say I believe Lester Lowe should be checked out.
answer: That can be arranged.

question: Mr. Haller said he'd check him out, and guess what? No one sees him again!
answer: And what do you suggest I do about it, dear boy?

question: I want you to turn this into a silver bullet.
answer: You're not going to let it go, are you?

question: I saw what I saw.
answer: Marty, the moon wasn't even full!

question: No one knows how cancer begins, either- or exactly what it is- but people still believe in it.
answer: The kid is eleven years old and already he sounds like a Jesuit. A French Jesuit.

question: I think he's going to come for me. Not just because I know who he is, but because I hurt him. Only I don't think he'll try again as Lowe.
answer: Dear boy, you have gone right out of your mind.

question: All right. I give up. Yes. If either of you ever tells anyone I even bought a piece of this story, werewolves will be the least of your problems. It's just a gag, that's all. What would you shoot a silver .22 bullet at, anyway?
answer: Remember, Al... we'll be at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston tomorrow night! Or at the funeral parlor. It's Stickney and-

question: -and Babcock, I remember. Now go on!
answer: And don't open the door for any trick or treaters even if they come!

question: We won't!
answer: You kids go to bed on time! You've got school tomorrow!

question: If you keep doing that, you're going to bump your head, sissy. Give my love to Mama- tell her I'll see her Thursday.
answer: I will- be good, kids.

question: Jane-
answer: Would you kids go to bed? My head's starting to ache.

question: It's here! It's outside!
answer: Jane, it's just a power fai-

question: Reeeal slow, Maa-aaarty- Bastard Marty!
answer: He points the gun and pulls the trigger. There's only a click. An expression of dismay on his face.

question: Kill you...
answer: He drags himself so he's half propped against the hall wall. He pulls the trigger again. Click! Dismay becomes fear. Holding the gun in both hands now, he pulls the trigger a third time. Click!
